POLICY LETTER, Hk
October 26, 19bl
I HAVE BEEN TRAVELLING,.. .AND I©RE TO COMB: Started the rounds of stations early
this week by making a three-point touch in Michigan, first to Hugh Masters of the
Kellogg Foundation in Battle Greek, Masters impressed me as being a very fine guy,
deeply interested in educational radio, genuinely anxious that NAEB run its own
show and that Kellogg help in every way possible. Masters formerly was at Ohio
State, originally from Texas, While at OSU he either worked with or knew first¬
hand the old radio education project of Keith Tyler’s, Inasmuch as ny brother was
one of those people, we swapped stories on people mutually known, Hugh is also a
farmer, actively managing 160 acres just outside Battle Creek, and so we talked
considerable agriculture# Toward our particular ends, he had many ideas on organi¬
sations, how they are set up, how they can best operate. He gave me many leads
which I shall attempt to review and which undoubtedly will be of value to us as we
strengthen our organisation. He plans to be in Biloxi about 2h hours, from
Thursday noon until Friday noon, I am sure you mil all agree with ey e/valuation
when you meet him©
The second visit was to Bob Coleman at WKAR and incidentally to the new Kellogg
Foundation Hotel which is called there a Continuing Study Center, A really lush
place that would be ideal for some of our future meetings either short-term or
AXlerton length, I imagine it is as busy as the Minnesota Continuing Study
Center, so any booking would have to be done well in advance, Nice chat with
Bob Coleman and his good wife, and I have a better picture of their operation now0
Next to Wally Game&u’s spot at Western Michigan State Teachers College, Carneau
lias a miniature Waldo Abbot set-up—really nice, top floor, new building, not too
much equipment but what’s there is good, Wally operates on a shoestring but with
the complete cooperation of his administration, Wally is strong for the tape net¬
work-says it has been the thing that enabled him to adequately program 2$ hours a
week*,oIf other visits are as cordial and revealing as these two, we should have
a rather tremendous body of knowledge of what education stations of the nation are
doing, *%
THE MAIL WAS HEAVY: The desk was piled high alter a week’s absence. Among things
noted,,,T,E. Bennett of Schenectady tells me that they have recently lost their
regular spot on a local AM outlet but have been offered night-time on that outlet
because of TV competition. The first instance of this I have noted. He has also
completed arrangements to use G,Eo»s outlet as much as he wants but now would like
to buy 100 or 200 AM-FM radios and asks, "Do you know a good cheap source?*,,,,©
Edgar Will of the University of Hawaii sits in an enviable position without any
money. There is no FM on the Islands but by the same token there are plenty of
AM channels available. He asks the usual question, "Anybody know whero I can find
money to start a station ? "., o,, Sydney Head is away from the University of Miami
working on his Ph,D, Oliver Griswold is the Acting Director©.,.©Ed Adams says that
due to some building difficulty, he is having to delay the start of bis operation
until November 13,,,,oKeith Nighbert says that they are getting ready to change
from three to ei^ht hours daily about the first of the year,,.,,Bob Higgy writes

about a note to Bill?©Herb Hake gave me the low-down on Iowa State Teachers
